message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The X-linked recessive disorder suggests a coagulation factor deficiency. Among the options, only factor VIII deficiency causes hemophilia A, which is X-linked. Von Willebrand factor deficiency is autosomal recessive or dominant, factor XI deficiency causes hemophilia C, and protein C deficiency causes thrombophilia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The X-linked recessive disorder suggests a clotting factor deficiency, and among the options, only factor VIII is associated with such a disorder, which is hemophilia A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Factors XI and protein C deficiencies are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The X-linked recessive disorder and prolonged bleeding suggest a clotting factor deficiency. Among the options, Factor VIII deficiency is the most likely cause, as it is the most common cause of inherited bleeding disorders. Von Willebrand factor deficiency can also cause prolonged bleeding, but it is not X-linked recessive. Factor XI deficiency and Protein C deficiency are rare and do not typically cause prolonged bleeding after tooth removal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The X-linked form of hemophilia affects Factor VIII, which is important for blood clotting. Von Willebrand factor is also important for blood clotting but is not linked to the X chromosome. Factor XI deficiency and Protein C deficiency are not X-linked recessive disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since it is an X-linked recessive disorder and only the male siblings are affected, the most likely deficiency is of Factor VIII, which is deficient in Hemophilia A. Von Willebrand factor deficiencies can also cause bleeding disorders, but they are usually not X-linked recessive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prolonged bleeding after tooth extraction suggests a clotting factor deficiency, and the fact that it is X-linked recessive suggests a deficiency in Factor VIII. Von Willebrand factor deficiency is also a clotting disorder but it is autosomal dominant. Factor XI deficiency can also cause bleeding but it is autosomal recessive. Protein C deficiency causes a hypercoagulable state, not bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The X-linked recessive disorder with prolonged bleeding suggests a deficiency of coagulation factor VIII, which is also known as hemophilia A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency is also associated with prolonged bleeding but it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Factor XI deficiency causes bleeding in Ashkenazi Jews but it is not X-linked. Protein C deficiency is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and causes thrombosis rather than bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the disorder is X-linked recessive, and the patient and his brother are affected but not the sisters, the most likely factor deficient is Factor VIII. It is also known that Factor VIII deficiency is more common in boys than girls. Von Willebrand factor deficiency is autosomal dominant and affects both sexes equally. Factor XI deficiency and Protein C deficiency are not X-linked.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and genetic confirmation suggest that the patient has hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency in Factor VIII. Von Willebrand factor deficiency is another common bleeding disorder, but it is not X-linked recessive. Factor XI deficiency and Protein C deficiency do not cause hemophilia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The X-linked recessive disorder and prolonged bleeding suggest a deficiency in a clotting factor. Among the options, Factor VIII is an X-linked factor and a deficiency can cause hemophilia A, which is consistent with the patient’s symptoms. Von Willebrand factor deficiency and Factor XI deficiency are both autosomal disorders, while Protein C deficiency causes a hypercoagulable state, not prolonged bleeding.
